commentBody: Hi Sam, The trickier thing about tricky clue 52A is that the correct answer has two spellings, so one must really wait for the crosses. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/ocher

Who'da thought there would be a puzzle about bottoms?  Apparel, that is.

I only have one criticism, though.  For 17A, I might have clued it with "War and Peace" rather than the "Odyssey".  I get it, the latter is a story about a long trip, but that's different from a long story.  The "Odyssey" wasn't an especially long story, as stories go, while "War and Peace," at approximately 1200 pages, is known for its length as much as for its content.
A cute theme, but maybe too cute; but an easy one to fill out.
Well done!  Clever, amusing, rather satisfying.  Kudos!
Cute n' easy. (Just how I like 'em)
9A uses a less common spelling.
Cute theme for a Tuesday.  I liked SLEEPTIGHTS and BILLIEJEANS, although I haven’t made up my mind about Ms. Eilish’s music yet.

About the column:

I don't think of fancy restaurants when I see the word CRUET.  I think about the supermarket brand Good Seasons salad dressing mix, which, when it first appeared in my younger days, could be purchased for under a buck, CRUET included.  And so called.

Also, to piggyback Barry's comment about OCHRE, your alternative "olive" has never appeared in its 291 times as an entry with a clue mentioning "earth tones".  OCHRE, however, has appeared 165 times, with 47 clues including the word "earth(y)":  earth tone, earthy color, earthy hue, etc.  OCHER has appeared 127 times, with 33 "earth(y)" clues.  I think Barry hit it on the head in saying that the choice was most likely between the two spellings of OCHRE/ER.
I was a little slow on figuring out why NAPA was a place for grape nuts. D'oh! (I probably shouldn't admit that.) Cute theme.
A lovely, breezy Tuesday puzzle!  I hope to see more puzzles from Barbara Lin!
Learned some new words today and good theme

I’m surprised to see the gender-neutral clue “guitarist, informally” solve to the gender-specific AXMAN. 

It wouldn’t have lost anything to clue it with  something like “guitar guy, informally.”
Why is a guitarist an axman? That is the one entry I could not explain.
What a very clever theme! Probably my favorite ever.

Not only do the themes provide punny delights, there are so many "make me smile" answers such as NAPA for place for grape nuts (as an oenophile, I especially loved that one), PLANK for hard core exercise, and PANE.

Also some great 80s and 90s references with final frontier (raise your hand if you read this clue in JL Picard/Patrick Stewart's voice) and etch a sketch (I wonder how many new solvers have no idea what this is)?

An 8 minute joy of a puzzle that made my evening.

Any puzzle touting TATERTOTs is okay by me.
Another terrific Toughened Up Tuesday offering.
Fun themers.

Thanks, Barbara

The puns that weren’t part of the clothing theme were better than the real groaners that were, like NAPA, PANE, etc. Also liked the misdirection with Nadal making me think of LOVE in terms of tennis. Appreciated some of the educational clues.

Possible cure for your addiction to buying Levis?

JEANS THERAPY

Your favorite underwear?

TOP DRAWERS

Where to find the latest in high-cut pants.

AISLE OF CAPRIS

A delight to solve. Car antenna and big cheese, quirky cluing. Everything we could wish for in a Tuesday puzzle.

Now that we've done bottoms, what's next?

END UP ON TOPS of course!

[Rod on the road] was worth the price of admission.  The puns were fun but that was inspired.  I wracked my brain trying to remember TV programs that follow some guy around while he talks about the scenery and local color, until the crosses finally gave me his "name."  [Well, duh!]

Barbara Lin, you gave us a delightful puzzle, nice and chewy for a Tuesday, and full of giggles.  Thank you.  We're all congratulating you, too.
Yesterday was fast; today was fast too—I enjoyed this but its already over! Nice all around. 🙂

What a fun theme! I’m always amazed by the clever ideas constructors come up with. 

Congratulations, Barbara.


When an AXMAN performs does he wear rock bottoms?

This was one of the toughest Tuesdays for me, and I don't really know why.
It wasn't because of the themers – once I got one, I got all.
It was because of the rest of the fill, a lot of which I was blanking out on. 

But I'm not complaining. 
A bit of a challenge on a Tuesday is a great thing, making for a fun solve.

I loved the theme and the puzzle as well. 
Thank you, Ms. Lin. for a very lively puzzle!
southwest corner was a nightmare for me, i filled in TMI instead of IMO, cut me MORE slack instead of SOME, but most embarrassing was mixing up RUTH bader ginsberg with RUBE goldberg...

Interesting to read that a constructor as talented as Barbara Lin was expecting "another rejection".  I mean, I suppose everyone has an off day (or an off puzzle), but since we don't get to see the rejects, hard to believe she's ever gotten that dreaded email.

Now that I've gotten my Barbara Lin fix, I need a little Kameron Austin Collins. It's been too long!

Cute puzzle that got us going bottoms up. Lots of fun figuring things out.

Thanks, Barbara Lin!

I will admit, when I saw the clue about “bottoms decorated with characters from ‘The Odyssey’”, I had an image of two drunken English professors entering a tattoo shop. 

Bottoms up!
Can't remember the last time I saw a car with a visible antenna

"You're wearing Levi's? But your parents don't."
"Must be recessive jeans."

("Seams reasonable.")
I found this puzzle to be very daffy in the best possible way!  Great job, Barbara Lin!
Great theme.  Good fun.
One who only drives the *best* Swedish cars, maybe? https://images.app.goo.gl/p61q91c3BfvRp3Ug9

TBH, IMO,TSK - but only OER some of the shorter stuff like HAS, OHO, and ESP.

The theme phrases - they had legs.
This was a great grid that I enjoyed alot. Constructors never fail to bedazzle me with amazing themes and clever clues. Great job!
Very fun puzzle today! I loved the theme entries! I desperately wanted love for Nadal to solve to CERO so that held me up a bit but otherwise smooth sailing!
Good one, Barbara! Your sense of humor worked for me this morning.

This was a great grid!
BILLIE JEANS had me laugh out loud. Great work.

I have only one question: how are LEMONS related to car owners? Is there some reference I don't get? Thank you :)
I hate puns so much. Whenever there is a puzzle like this it makes me want to quit crosswords forever.
Such a fun puzzle! I spelled ‘Macao’ as ‘Macau’ though, which appears to be another acceptable spelling, and caused me no small amount of confusion and wondering what ‘uks’ are!
I wouldn't have gotten AXMAN had I not seen this scene from the Simpsons, https://youtu.be/YPhO5g39vpg.
C’mon, ‘fess up. Am I the only one who tried UGLYSWEATER in 48A?

WOW,   great Tuesday puzzle with a fun theme and nice variety of entries in addition to the clever theme.  

Nice comment from Barbara as well and I look forward to more from her.
Another excellent Barbara Lin puzzle.  She can do any day of the week justice.  [Place for grape nuts?] for NAPA gave me a laugh.

Purchase for a window shopper made me groan in that happy way. Do the kids still play with Etch-a-sketches that have knobs? Or has some digital app replaced them?  Overall, I really enjoyed solving this one. 

Amee
Keene, NH

My only gripe about a lovely Barbara Lin 
Tuesday, or
any fun early week puzzle

is that it’s over so doggone fast.

Archives, here I come!

Happy Tuesday all!

That was fun. Good long workout for me, of course, but catching on to the trick was the big turning point and that's always a nice touch.

One of my favorite constructors. Had to go back and look at some of her previous puzzles. Just as an example her debut from January 23, 2020. Four theme answers: 

ROCKSTHEBOWTIE
GIMMEASINAI
THEGOODWIFI
FREEVERSAILLES

I'm done. 

..

Fun puzzle but how is an OBOE a cousin to a French Horn?  The former is a reed instrument and the latter a brass?  Maybe I just needed the relationship to be more distant [third cousin twice removed from a French Horn]?

Just a package of lovely today.

Clever never-done-before theme that brought me from neutral to that filled-with-smiles feeling. That is a gift.

Great care in cluing. 
•	Misdirects: [Warning sound] for GROWL, which got me picturing things like alarms and sirens; [Small part] for CAMEO, which got me thinking about physical things; [Love, for Rafael Nadal] because “love” has meanings in both tennis and feelings.  
•	TILs – that ants communicate with pheromones, and even that Doritos have MSG.  
•	Wordplay: [Hard core exercise] for PLANK, [Going rate?] for MPH, and the magnificent [Place for grape nuts?] for NAPA.
•	Riddles, such as [Body part that may be green] for IRIS, that had me taking a thorough mental body inventory, and still not get it until the crosses came.

Sweet extras: Three palindromes (WOW, OHO, ANNA) and fetching answers ORACLE, GLEAN, CRUET, and CAMEO.

Barbara, you are on a roll. This is your third puzzle in three months, and it’s easy to see why, as you infuse your puzzles with quality.  Today’s shimmered with wit, beauty, humor, and skill.  Thank you for making it!

a full wardrobe of puns . . .

… And All I Got Was This Lousy T-Shirt.


Fun puzzle.

"Rod for the road" had me thinking Rod Stewart songs, or suspension rod. Can't say as I've ever thought of the ANTENNA as a rod.

Ha! And the category of TMI summers often find me solving pant free.

Had hemmesomeslacks as my gangsta fill, but.....

Thank you Barbara, nice job.
14A reminded me of OMNI magazine.  As a teenager, much of my allowance went to OMNI, Asimov’s, Analog, F&SF, etc.

Had fun guessing the themers with a minimum of crosses.  Well done.  

[Many pocketed shorts worn during a critical play?]

CLUTCHCARGOS
Lots of original stuff, at least to me. Nice job.

(I find myself again being OT for the current puzzle, just trying to post about puzzle from over the weekend. Emufied as usual.)

The [Half of LV] clue, that ended up being the Las half of Las Vegas, got many people thinking about how to represent [Half of 55] in Roman numerals. Of course the Romans could represent incredibly fine fractions, but with an interesting twist:
while the numbers for integers are in a tens-based system (IVXLCDM), fractions were based on a twelve-part division.

S was the letter used for semi(s), 1/2, but it actually meant 6/12. So half of LV would be XXVIIS.

The sign • was used for the twelfth part of a unit, called uncia. Uncia has come down to our language in two paths: an “ounce” is the twelfth part of a pound (originally), and an “inch” is the twelfth part of a foot.

It also survives in the name of the pattern ⁙, “quincunx”, which represented 5/12. The pattern is used in laying out orchards, and on dice and cards, and lots of other ways today. Quinque + uncia became the portmanteau quincunx.

For practical reasons, they later added a sign for 1/24, Σ, meaning half of a twelfth, which allowed for the sign Σ•, meaning three-halves of a twelfth, to give the fraction 1/8.

When in Rome…
Can't believe Rube Goldberg never even built any of the machines he drew. They shouldn't have awarded him the patents then!

Today's puzzle reminds me of when we got a substitute teacher for the day and what was expected to be the same old routine suddenly became a fun and attention grabbing class. Drop in any time, Ms. Lin! Brava!
This was a perfect puzzle.
I use the Android Games app, and cannot find the theme hint. Someone said use the I information button, but it's not there. Any clues?

Fun theme. Lovely solve. Thanks Barbara.

OT: there’s an article on flooding in the USA in today’s NYT that links to a companion article based on a system set up in my neck of the woods as a way of alleviating flooding in lived in areas. Some years ago farmland was returned to its original salt marsh origins, in a bid to stop the river Parrott from flooding nearby villages. The Steart marshes are now an amazing wetland full of bird and insect life. I live on the inland stretch of the Parrott; the marshes now absorb most of the potential flood water and provide homes for birds. What’s not to love?
Hope all those affected by flooding in the recent hurricanes are recovering.

I loved the aha moment when I figured out the theme! I didn't use any helps for today's puzzle. I know that's not like getting the Friday/Saturday puzzles without help, but it makes me very happy to have grappled with this and come out on top! Have a great day!

I like everything about this puzzle -- from the cute and imaginative theme...to the smooth and junk-free grid...to the lively cluing featuring the occasional offbeat clue like the ones for IRIS and LEMONS.  And much better to have four nifty themers than three themers and a tepid revealer.  This is the sort of themed puzzle that no AI bot will ever dream up.  It's much too quirky and idiosyncratically human.  Very nice job, Barbara.
Clueing was jean-ius today! Thanks to Barbara and eds!

Wow, this puzzle might have been constructed just for me, full of in jokes and ear worms! Billie Jeans, is not my lover... However, the most persistent of ear worms will be a very particular one. I was in the musical Pajama Game in freshman year of college, and now I will be hearing the Sleep Tite anthem, from the beginning of the annual company picnic, all day long: "Sleep-Tite, Sleep-Tite, Sleep-Tite we pledge our hearts' devotion to thee, to thee, oh Sleep-Tite, best in the land, with your reinforced buttons, and stretch-proof waist band!" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JcbgojnJklI

Super fun, breezy with a touch of crunch and grin inducing to boot.
Brava.

One of those themes that, to me, feels a bit too contrived. Perhaps if BILLIEJEANS was different, so the theme clues were all slight perversions of common turns of phrase I would prefer it, but as is, it didn’t quite hit the spot for me.
Great puzzle! Enjoyable word play. Thanks

Sparkling puzzle, clever laugh-out-loud cluing! Barbara, you made my day. And kudos to Sam, for your particularly punchy (punny?) column!
You had me at "grape nuts."  I really needed the smiles today and this entertaining puzzle provided plenty of them.  Thank you.

If you substitute "stars and planets" for "characters from The Odyssey," you get SPACE JAMS. Yes, I'm still flashing back to the '80s.

RAD!

My mom was a big crossword fanatic when we used to do it in the daily paper in pencil. I do enjoy doing these online, but must admit that I get a bit vexed when the answer is two or more words. Today there was a four word answer. The crosswords in the newspaper used to give a clue by putting the indication (wds) indicating that it was multiple words or a phrase. Maybe that's too easy?
As a Catholic altar boy, the first time I ran across CRUET: these are used for the serving of the wine and water at Mass.

I enjoyed the theme quite a bit
"Clothing remarks..."  Groan but funny.
What a terrific, hilarious theme! Thanks for bringing joy to my Tuesday, Barbara Lin! Please keep those puzzles coming. Also loved your comments, Sam, as always. Happy Tuesday everyone 😊

I feel like when an answer is explicitly gendered, the NYTimes often does a fairly good job of adding a qualifier to the clue acknowledging that the answer isn't the exclusive solution. Often that takes the form of including a word like "some" or "for one" or "perhaps" something along those lines. That they chose not to qualify the "Guitarist" / AXMAN pair at all was mildly disappointing, but I'm not crying foul too loudly. I'll simply try to counterbalance that with the video of Kaki King's Ted Talk performance https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_7LX4FW7TEI
I could’ve sworn it was “Macau” but it looks as though it could be either way. Today I learned!
was confused about macao/macau, would've gotten that one sooner otherwise! still a fun solve i liked the theme!

@Barry Ancona 

I agree.

It seems Sam was thinking of [Earth] as the planet when it is, in fact, soil.
Earth tones is an expression commonly used in oil painting. Amongst them are ochre, burnt sienna, raw umber, and Venetian red, to name a few.
Olive is not an earth tone, though it is an Earth tone.
@Barry Ancona I usually plug in the answer and leave the questionable letters blank but I forgot this time. Thankfully the odds were in my favor!

sotto voce, In contemporary interior design, an [Earth tone] is any color associated with "natural materials or landscapes," so olive could be a valid answer ... but I wouldn't expect it on a Tuesday. That's why I said "trickier," not "the actual trick." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earth_tone

N.B. OLIVE has been an answer
291 times in the NYT XWP ...
not once clued as [Earth tone].
@sotto voce I stand by what I said! Olive is an earthy tone! (Black and kalamata varieties, admittedly, are the exception.)

Sam,

You wrote [Earth tone] twice. 
You didn't write earthy tone. 
But, as above, you are correct 
(in the more recent use of the term).

In both uses, olive is understood
to mean olive green, a yellowish
green, the color of an unripe olive.

@Sam Corbin 

Who am I to contest such assurance, lol?

It prompted me to research and it appears we're both right – you in interior design, and me in oil painting.

However...per BA's notes about the [Earth tone] clue in the NYT, it would seem the reference is then always to oil painting, no?

(Ducking and running.)

sotto voce,

Past results are no guarantee...

After today's discussion,
look for a constructor
or editor to clue OLIVE
on a Friday or Saturday
as [Earth tone}.

@Steve L 

Although the clue references the specific story, the definition of the word odyssey begins “a long…” which one could argue makes it a good choice for a Tuesday clue.

@Jim 

I notice how you didn’t write the whole definition. Every definition of lower-case “odyssey” describes a long journey, not a long story. 

Homer’s “Odyssey” was a not-so-long story about a long journey. 

One could argue that anyone who knows that the “Odyssey” is not that long a work might find the clue suboptimal.

Steve,

OTOH, I think
wearing shorts
is closer to "Odyssey" 
than to "War and Peace."

@Ethan 

But what about the puzzles?

@Janna Straub Google Ngram Viewer disagrees with you: https://tinyurl.com/4skepmvh The O version is over three times as common as the U version, and has always been more common. But even if that were not the case, there's nothing wrong with a less common spelling being the answer. The cross needs to be OKS, not uks. (MACAO outperforms Macau in NYT appearances, 46 to 17.) (On a related note, OCHRE also outnumbers "ocher" in Google Ngram Viewer, even when just searching for American English. This also doesn't matter when doing a crossword; both versions appear regularly, with the former spelling ahead, 164-127.)

@Janna Straub 

I’m also more accustomed to seeing it spelled with a U. When I lived in Hong Kong in the 90’s, it was almost always spelled Macau (or it was written in Chinese characters). I often took the ferry from Hong Kong to Macau.

@Janna Straub. While the Google snapshot has MACAO in its heading, in the text it spells it as Macau.
Both the C.I.A. World Factbook and Australian Dept. of Foreign Affairs give the (Portuguese based) Macau as part of the “Official” name.

@Steve L 

Your claim is only accurate for the uncapitalized case (macao/macau) but the two spellings are nearly identical when the M is capitalized (Macao/Macau) and the U spelling is far more common when all case-sensitivity is ignored - at least during the past 30 years.

I have primarily seen this word on maps which I'm guessing are not well represented by this dataset. In the maps I've seen (not exhaustive) the U spelling is much more common. 

Furthermore, the Wikipedia page for Macau uses the O spelling 62  times and the U spelling 292 times. So I think Janna is justified here.

Any Catholic altar servers will be familiar with the word and the vessels used in liturgies. Often cut crystal.

Add the “wait for the crossing” on Macao/Macau.

@Norman That’s two mentions of Napa this month. And Grape Nuts is my favorite cereal. It’s all working out for me.

Excellent theme today. I had the promising LONGBOARDSHORTS in there for too long—I guess I didn’t like The Odessey as much as some?

@ES Jack I don't think it would have gained anything, either. Clues don't have to be without exception; just because there are female guitarists out there doesn't mean the clue is wrong. There's no equivalent term for a female guitarist, and the clue is literally the dictionary definition (or at least one of them) for AXMAN: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/axman The only definition I could find for "axwoman" involves a literal ax: https://en.m.wiktionary.org/wiki/axwoman But here's an axwoman, er, a female guitarist, with amazing skills: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XcTRllYrkik (I keep wondering why this girl isn't a real star and not just a YouTube star.)
@Steve L I could play like that I’d still want to be called axman even though I’m a girl. It sounds too cool to resist lol.

@Steve L

My point is not that the clue was misleading or confusing. It’s that most people, when asked to picture a guitarist, will picture a man. I think it’s worth taking every opportunity to shatter that perception. (Speaking personally, as an axwoman.)

@Asher
A guitar is colloquially known as an "ax", hence the one playing it would be an ax man. That's why my initial answer of axer didn't fit...

@Bruce Make that "bass," not "base." An electric bass guitar. 

That was embarrasing.

@Bruce 
Plus you left an S out of embarrassing.
May as well go back to bed, eh?

I can "fuzz" my vision as much as possible, and I still can't "see" an AXE ... but okay, fine.  It's "in the language."  My question is:  would you still call a classical guitar (no wires, amps, junk, weird shapes) an axe/ax?

@Mean Old Lady As noted, my teacher, a classical guitarist who tours regularly and who has performed on NPR nationally, says it sometimes. It's done with some humor, but it's still done. It's hard for me to imagine any guitarist (any American one, at least) who isn't familiar with the term.

@DocP I think the 60s got there first...

Or has Shatner been cancelled for some reason?
@DocP As a 2005 baby, I can confirm that kids do indeed still use etch-a-sketches (at least I did).

@Vaer 

I am blessed (cursed?) to have great TATER TOTS nearby. Maybe a little too close for my cardiovascular health! Haha. 

Freddie's Bar makes them perfectly crispy on the outside, creamy on the inside... (Also an eponymous version that's like loaded potato skins and total overkill.)

But my fave are at the local ramen place, South Slope Ramen. They give them the takoyaki treatment with okonomayaki sauce and bonito flakes. 

And yes, I really enjoyed that entry in the puzzle! 😋

@G 
I often have Cascadian Farms's "healthy" Spud Puppies in my freezer for emergency situations.

@Vaer 

Ooh, those sound like something I'll have to check out! 

For "emergencies", of course.
 
🙂
@G I prefer the Fries a la Freddy, I am not the biggest tater tot guy because they make me feel like I’m still in middle school.

@Charles Nelson Reilly 

I don't think I've ever tried Freddy's fries! 

For me, tots are a rare treat, less commonly found than fries... (What does it say about me that I also can recommend the tots at American Retro in Hell's Kitchen? Lol.)

Also, I never had the "pleasure" of tater tots in my youth! Is that because they didn't exist way back then (the 70's), or a quirk of my upbringing? 🤔

@john ezra -- [Chef's kiss!]






Et tu, emu.

@dutchiris 

I was wondering if there was a [Rod] Stewart song that somehow was a shoe-in for this clue. 

A verse from Maggie Mae, perhaps? But then that's not officially a *Rod Stewart* release, since it was when he was with The Faces.

I had it almost entirely filled in from crosses when it clicked. Lovely!

@sotto voce 

If you had a similar line of thinking, then I'm in very good company. Your taste in and knowledge of music is top-notch! 

(Always nice to read a comment of yours as well! I have been too remiss of late.)

🙂

@G 

Thank you for the lovely compliment(s)!

Yes you have been "remiss," but it's always very special when you show up.
🙂

@Warren 

What a find!

I have to say it had me worried for him, though. He doesn't sound just his usual raspy. He sounds hoarse, like he's about to lose his voice any second now! 😂

All this talk about him reminded me of when I was an interpreter at the first Rock in Rio festival and had to deal with his antics on two occasions. Nobody else was brave enough to do it, but I was very calm and not easily flustered, so I was the chosen one.
He was a feisty and rowdy one who thought he was God's gift to humanity and, especially, women. 
I resolved the issues but for a long time thereafter shunned his music because of the personal dislike for the personality of the man.

Eventually, I was able to give him the benefit of the doubt that time would have matured him, and I dropped my resistance and went to his concert, which was pretty great. 

But it remains that the only way I listen to his music is if it comes on the radio. I own none of his cd's.

@sotto voce 

NO! 
Not Mr. “Da Ya Think I’m Sexy?”  

Only like his oldest stuff, but never had any illusions about his sense of humility.

Glad you got through it, but still sounds like a unique opportunity and experience!

@Warren 

"NO! 
Not Mr. 'Da Ya Think I’m Sexy?'"

ROFL!!!

Yes, it was a great experience, with many insider stories after ten days of interacting with musicians.

I only came to regret that, because I was so blasé about fame and not one to be starstruck, it never even occurred to me to take some pictures with them as other interpreters did. Oh well. But the stories are still better than any photo would have been, lol.

@Warren 

Thanks for that link. I haven't listened to much Rod Stewart in the past 40 years, but I always liked his early '70's stuff.
@Anita I laughed out loud at your last sentence. Thanks for brightening my day!

@Anita 

Note to Mike in Munster:

You have competition!

(You GO, girl!)

@Anita 
Did I have a pair of black-and-red spandex pants in the '80s? Yes I did.

@sotto voce I inexplicably had to jump around like it was a Friday or Saturday. I think because the clues were plainly written and the answers were also plain (not boring, just plain!) I had to think more about both.

@Joya 

I like that explanation for what maybe happened to me.

Thanks for chiming in.

Have a wonderful afternoon (and I hope you got that job you were nervous about interviewing for!)
@sotto voce I didn’t but there is something more wonderful on the horizon! ;) thank you for asking! I hope you’re having a wonderful day as well!

@Joya 

When something goes "wrong" I always like to say that it's the wrong that turns out right. We just need to be patient.

And so I know in my heart that not getting that job will turn out right.
Three cheers to the more wonderful on the horizon!

In fact, I might go ahead and start popping that champagne on your behalf. ;-)
@sotto voce ayeeeeee thank you so so much!!!!

@Pezhead 

Please do NOT poke that bear!!
@Bill in Yokohama Yep, a typical modern car has about ten antennas, and none of them are rods.
@Bill in Yokohama  2001 Nissan Sentras have them. I drove mine for 18 years.

@Bill in Yokohama 
My Jeep has a whip antenna. Never called it a ROD, though, but I might be channeling my father, the wave propagation guru.

Mike,

Once again it seems you’ve dungareesonable job.


(I’m not being disrespectful - but you truly managed to flippants.)

@JohnWM et al

Do you think a Looney like our Mike wears
PANTALOONS?

@Mike

@CaptainQuahog - the one in which I read the clue too quickly and mistook English for French!

@Matt Kopans - well, they are cousins in one sense: the French horn is German, not French; the English horn is French, not English.

Cor anglais - the French name for the alto oboe - originally meant “angled horn”, but was mistranslated as “english horn”. This shouldn’t be surprising, since English / Anglo- take their name from the tribes that lived in the “angle” formed by the Danish peninsula.

@Vaer - har har…you’re not wrong

The now-abandoned and extremely complex system of coinage in Imperial Britain is a simple inheritance from the old Roman way of dividing the pound (an actual pound of metal / alloy) into useful parts. All the groats, shillings, guineas, tuppence, sovereigns, etc. ad nauseam, are derived from taking 12 parts and dividing them 20 ways.

It is a great example of the physical world (actual lumps of metal, actual coins) interacting with the figural world (abstractions about value and worth) - which we are still working our way through today. Bits of silver, meet bitcoin.

48 teaspoons; 16 Tablespoons; 1 cup. The imperial system keeps the twelfth divisions alive, millenia later.

@David Connell 
We had:
12 pennies to a shilling
20 shillings to a pound. 
21 shillings to a guinea
Coins had nicknames (but not now with decimal coinage)
Six penny coin - a tanner
One shilling  - a bob
Three penny coin - thrupence
Two pennies - tuppence
Two shilling coin - florin
A coin worth 2 shillings and six pennies - 2 and 6
Two of them my father always called - half a dollar!

@Martin There was an exhibit at the Smithsonian many years ago that actually constructed two of his devices. They worked, but I imagine there were a lot of animatronic cheats. There were also plastic models of a few of his cartoons and those, once assembled, did the job. Google "Rube Goldberg model kits."

Paul,

If by "theme hint" 
you mean "puzzle title," 
only Sunday crosswords have titles.

@Paul 

The information button provides the title, but only Sunday puzzles have titles. 

Weekday puzzles may have a revealer, usually a long clue in the lower part of the grid or sometimes in the center, but many themes do not have such a revealer. 

This puzzle does not have a revealer. You are expected to glean the theme by noticing the SHORTS, JEANS, etc. at the ends of each long answer.

@Barry Ancona BILLIE JEAN is a common turn of phrase in several contexts Here's a video which might help you. https://youtu.be/ZuZxoprwxxY?si=HzkKatDwOSWLiLpb "A turn of phrase" refers to a unique or creative way of using words. It's all about expressing something in an unusual, interesting, or clever way. It's not just about what is said, but how it's said. @David Connell 

Pants = "not very good", "a bit rubbish". Pants in BritSpeak being underpants rather than outer legware.

I don't think it's of any great antiquity, It seemed to emerge in the 1980s through the alternative comedy circuit, and especially the Comic Relief charity which raises funds for international relief, particularly through its biennial telethon "Red Nose Day". The slogan one year early in the campaign was "Pants to Poverty".

I think I still have my original red plastic nose from1985, which I wore all day at work and in the evening at an otherwise extremely dull meeting of the London Labour Party executive.
